name: activated carbon production, granular from hard coal | activated carbon, granular | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/15255/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of granular activated carbon (GAC) from hard coal. Hard coal produced GAC is typical for Central Europe. To produce GAC, hard coal undergoes carbonisation and partial gasification (activation). Hard coal is first heated to temperatures over 700 degrees Celsius. The activation stage, in this dataset, is achieved through vaporisation at temperatures between 800 and 1000 degrees Celsius. Activation is the key step in producing GAC. The main energy requirements are 1.6 kWh electricity and 0.33 m3 of natural gas to heat 12 kg of water. The main source of data is Bayer et al. (2005) "Economical and ecological comparison of granular activated carbon (GAC) absorber refill strategies" and This dataset represents the treatment of 1 kg of spent granular activated carbon (GAC) from hard coal. GAC can be reactivated through the same process with which it is produced (http://www.calgoncarbon.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/02/Reactivation_Services_FAQ.pdf, accessed 20151209). Spent activated carbon is first heated to temperatures over 700 degrees Celsius. The activation stage, in this dataset, is achieved through vaporisation at temperatures between 800 and 1000 degrees Celsius. Activation is the key step in producing GAC. The main energy requirements are taken from "activated carbon production, granular from hard coal" dataset, in which for the burning of 3 kg of coal the requirements are: 1.6 kWh electricity and 0.33 m3 of natural gas to heat 12 kg of water. The main source of data is Bayer et al.  (2005) "Economical and ecological comparison of granular activated carbon (GAC) absorber refill strategies" and Munoz et al. (2007) Life-Cycle Assessment of a Coupled Advanced Oxidation-Biological Process for Wastewater Treatment: Comparison with Granular Activated Carbon Adsorption. Environmental Engineering Science, 24(5): 638-651.;The result of this activity is 1 kg of activated carbon from 3 kg of hard coal. To include the emissions for the carbonization of 2 kg of hard coal, the datasets for "heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, GLO 1992" was taken as a reference to model emissions and energy requirements. The original datasets represented: "the production of heat from a 1-10 MW hard coal industrial furnace filled with 1 MJ of egg coal. The stoker-boiler furnace fires egg coals with hard coal quality between long-flame coal and fat coal. As there is no module for egg coal, the hard coal supply mix is used. The lifetime of the furnace is 20 years, which corresponds to 5000 fully load hours per year. The heating value is 28.9 MJ/kg and the efficiency factor is 80%". 

From reception of hard coal.

This activity ends with produced 1 kg of granular activated carbon from 3 kg of hard coal. The datasets includes electricity consumption, the burning of natural gas for the vaporisation of water, water and the emissions from hard coal combustion.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2029:Manufacture of other chemical products n.e.c.

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: GAC from hard coal is common practice in Central Europe (Bayer et al. 2005)
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Reref to: Bayer et al. 2005. Economical and ecological comparison of granular activated carbon (GAC) absorber refill strategies. Water research (39), 1719-1728;Refer to: Munoz et al. 2007. Life-Cycle Assessment of a Coupled Advanced Oxidation-Biological Process for Wastewater Treatment: Comparison with Granular Activated Carbon Adsorption. Environmental Engineering Science. 5 (24), 638-651
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Partial extrapolation. Emissions for the combustion of hard coal are taken from the dataset "heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, GLO 1992". Uncertainty was adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Based on literature data:
Bayer et al. (2005) Economical and ecological comparison of granular activated carbonn (GAC) adsorber refill strategies. Water research, 39: 1719-1728
Munoz et al. (2007) Life-Cycle Assessment of a Coupled Advanced Oxidation-Biological Process for Wastewater Treatment: Comparison with Granular Activated Carbon Adsorption. Environmental Engineering Science, 24(5): 638-651.

exchanges.description:
The main sources of information used to create the dataset are: 
Bayer et al. 2005. Economical and ecological comparison of granular activated carbon (GAC) absorber refill strategies. Water research (39), 1719-1728
Munoz et al. 2007. Life-Cycle Assessment of a Coupled Advanced Oxidation-Biological Process for Wastewater Treatment: Comparison with Granular Activated Carbon Adsorption. Environmental Engineering Science. 5 (24), 638-651

Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). From radioactivity of the elements.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Particulate Matter, > 2.5 um and < 10um
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Cobalt II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation. To estimate the electricity consumption, data of the heating plant in Bern is evaluated. At full load 1.13% of the input energy is consumed as electricity. The installed capacity in auxiliary units is divided into induced draft fan (31%), primary air fan (13%), feed pump (39%), electric filter (11.8%), rust (0.8%), feeding (1.8%), slag chain (0.2%), oil supply control (0.9%) and secondary air (1.4%). It is assumed that the electricity consumption increases through part load operation. Additionally it must be considered that the observed heating plant has a capacity of about 38 MW. Therefore, it is assumed that 1.5% of the input energy is consumed as electricity.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product. Source (Fritsche et al. 1992) in the process for heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, Europe without Swizterland 1992. 
To the amount required for carbonisation, 1.6 kWh of electricity are added as an estimated requirement for activation (Bayer 2005).
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE

flow.name: Iodine
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=PL
Estimation. Stoker-boiler furnaces emit between 300kg and 1000kg of particles per TJin if there is no particle separation. With an average of 650kg per TJin, 600kg of fly ash and 2300kg of bottom ash occurs. It is assumed that 100% of the ash is disposed (worst-case-scenario). In individual cases a 100% recycling rate is possible as well.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). From radioactivity of the elements.

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). Emissions of trace elements were calculated using the ash content in the coal and average transfer coefficients for coal power plants with ash retention of 98 %.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Cadmium II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Modeled, based on “heat production, coal, emissions to air” - pdf-document on the dedicated talk page of ecoinvent (www.ecoinvent.org/documentation). The emission data are taken from the literature reporting measurements performed at the end of the 1980s in Germany and are based on the composition of the coal.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Antimony ion
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=PL
Estimation. Stoker-boiler furnaces emit between 300kg and 1000kg of particles per TJin if there is no particle separation. With an average of 650kg per TJin, 600kg of fly ash and 2300kg of bottom ash occurs. It is assumed that 100% of the ash is disposed (worst-case-scenario). In individual cases a 100% recycling rate is possible as well.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.

flow.name: Carbon monoxide, fossil
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Estimation. It is assumed that 2% of the feed water is additionally required as decarbonised water (6t per TJin). For wet purification 1.5t per TJin of water is needed. Due to the lack of information the water used for cleaning can not be considered.
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product.
Estimation. It is assumed that 2% of the feed water is additionally required as decarbonised water (6t per TJin). For wet purification 1.5t per TJin of water is needed. Due to the lack of information the water used for cleaning can not be considered. Source (Fritsche et al. 1992) in the process for heat production, at hard coal industrial furnace 1-10MW, Europe without Swizterland 1992. 
Amount was scaled to the amount of reference product. To the amount required for carbonisation, 12 kg of water are added as an estimated requirement for the generation of vapour for the activation step (Bayer 2005).
